title.text: HIT-CIR: An Unsupervised WSD System Based on Domain Most Frequent Sense Estimation

abstractContent.text: This paper presents an unsupervised system for all-word domain specific word sense disambiguation task.

entities.text: all-word domain specific word sense disambiguation task

abstractContent.text: This system tags target word with the most frequent sense which is estimated using a thesaurus and the word distribution information in the domain.
The thesaurus is automatically constructed from bilingual parallel corpus using paraphrase technique.
The recall of this system is 43.5% on SemEval-2 task 17 English data set.

introductionContent.text: Tagging polysemous word with its most frequent sense (MFS) is a popular back-off heuristic in word sense disambiguation (WSD) systems when the training data is inadequate.

entities.text: Tagging polysemous word with its most frequent sense (MFS)

introductionContent.text: In past evaluations, MFS from WordNet performed even better than most of the unsupervised systems (.
MFS is usually obtained from a large scale sense tagged corpus, such as SemCor (.
However, some polysemous words have different MFS in different domains.
For example, in the corpus, target word coach means "manager" mostly in the SPORTS domain but means "bus" mostly in the FINANCE domain.
So when the MFS is applied to specific domains, it needs to be re-estimated.
proposed an unsupervised predominant word sense acquisition method which obtains domain specific MFS without sense tagged corpus.
In their method, a thesaurus, in which words are connected with their distributional similarity, is constructed from the domain raw text.
Word senses are ranked by their prevalence score which is calculated using the thesaurus and the sense inventory.
In this paper, we propose another way to construct the thesaurus.
We use statistical machine: The architecture of HIT-CIR translation (SMT) techniques to extract paraphrase pairs from bilingual parallel text.
In this way, we avoid calculating similarities between every pair of words and could find semantic similar words or compounds which have dissimilar distributions.
Our system is comprised of two parts: the word sense ranking part and the word sense tagging part.
Senses are ranked according to their prevalence score in the target domain, and the predominant sense is used to tag the occurrences of the target word in the test data.

The word sense ranking part includes following steps.
1. Tag the POS of the background text, count the word frequency in each POS, and get the polysemous word list of the POS.
2. Using SMT techniques to extract phrase table 3.
Calculate the prevalence score of each sense of the target words, rank the senses with the score and obtain the predominant sense.
We applied our system on the English data set of SemEval-2 specific domain WSD task.

entities.text: English data set of SemEval-2 specific domain WSD task

introductionContent.text: This task is an all word WSD task in the environmental domain.
We employed the domain background raw text provided by the task organizer as well as the English WordNet 3.0 and the English-Spanish parallel corpus from Europarl (.
This paper is organized as follows.
Section 2 introduces how to rank word senses.
Section 3 presents how to obtain the most related words of the target words.
We describe the system settings in Section 4 and offer some discussions in Section 5.
